title: STAT 230 Data Science and Statistics
text: Course modality: in-person (see next section for information of meeting days, time, and location)

title: STAT 230 Data Science and Statistics
text:
Prerequisites
MATH 111 with a grade of C- or higher or placement through the Montclair State University Placement Test (MSUPT) or MATH 122 with a grade of C- or higher or AMAT 120 with a grade of C- or higher

title: Course Introduction
text:
Who am I?

Adriana Picoral (PhD, you can call me Adriana)
picorala@montclair.edu
Office:
Office hours: Tuesdays and Thursdays, 1:45pm to 3:30pm

title: Course Introduction
text:
Active Learning

I expect you to actively participate in class (that does not mean you have to speak to th entire group)
Lots of hands-on activities and discussions
We will be using Gradescope to submit in-class work and for homework assignments

title: Course Introduction
text:
Ice Breaker

Find at least one person to talk to.
Introduce yourself (name, major/program, anything else you’d like to share)
What is something you are good at and that took many hours of practice?

title: Course Introduction
text:
Course Overview
Understanding data is the primary focus of this course with emphasis on statistical techniques for gathering, analyzing, summarizing and communicating the results of these analyses.
Statistical software is used.
In my sections that means we will be coding in R.

title: Why statistics?
text:
What is statistics?
collection, organization, analysis, interpretation, and presentation of data
Claude’s answer

title: Why statistics?
text:
Some Questions
Here are some questions we can answer using statistics:

Are some airlines more likely to have delayed flights than others?
Over the last five years, what is the average time to complete a degree for Montclair State undergrads?
Does a new drug reduce the number of deaths in patients with severe heart disease?

title: Why statistics?
text:
Types of Questions

descriptive
comparative
relationship-based

Match each question in the previous slide with a question type

title: Why statistics?
text:
Descriptive Research Questions
Examples of how to start your descriptive question:

How many?
How often?
How frequently?
How much?
What percentage?
What proportion?

title: Why statistics?
text:
Comparative research questions

What are the differences?

title: Why statistics?
text:
Relationship-based questions?

What is the relationship between …?
What is the effect of … on …?

title: Why statistics?
text:
Comparison
Go to the Bureau of Transportation Statistics website and try to answer the following question:

Which of the 4 largest airlines in the US (American, Delta, Southwest, United) has the best On-Time Arrival Performance between January and September 2024?

title: Why statistics?
text:
Descriptive/Summary statistics

American: 69.77%
Southwest: 76.78%
United: 76.87%
Delta: 80.36%

Can these summary statistics help you make decisions about which airline to fly?

title: Why statistics?
text:
Inferential Statistics
Are the differences across groups “real”?

title: Why statistics?
text:
Probability

If you flip a coin 100 times, how many times will the coin land heads?
Suppose it lands 51 heads – can we conclude that the coin is not fair?

Observed differences may be real – or they may be a result of chance (natural variation)
We use statistics to determine if differences are large enough that we can reject the hypothesis that they are due to chance

title: Variables
text:
Types of Variables

personality: categorical
eye_color: categorical
siblings: numeric, discrete
sleep_hours: numeric, continuous
sleep_time: categorical, ordinal
rating: categorical, ordinal or numeric, discrete

title: Variables
text:
Explanatory and response variables

Response variables are also known as dependent variables
Explanatory variables are also knows as independent variables
A response variable is the variable that is measured and is expected to change based on the manipulation of other variables (the explanatory variables)
The explanatory variables are expected to affect the response variable
Correlation does not imply causation

title: Variables
text:
Disney Movies vs. Vehicle Thefts

Disney Movies vs. Vehicle Thefts

title: Variables
text:
Association vs. causation

Association: when two variables show some connection (like correlation) with one another
Association does not imply causation
Causation can only be inferred from a randomized experiment

title: Getting started with R
text:
Coding Environment
We will be applying the statistical concepts we learn in this class using the programming language R.
I will be using RStudio Desktop during class demonstrations.

Install R and Download RStudio

Alternatively (if you are unable to download and install software in your computer), you can use Posit Cloud

title: Getting started with R
text:
Working within Projects
We will always be working with projects in this class (reproducible research reasons)
Demonstration on how to create a new project in RStudio

title: Getting started with R
text:
Packages
There are a number of packages for statistics in R.
We will be using tidyverse – widely used
Demonstration on how to install packages
